prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The three requested tunings in band-4 are carefully chosen to maximize the coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.
While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000 km/s (>2 FWHM) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high-velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize the coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500 km/s blueward of their CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our band-3 tunings. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises.
Finally, we note that the galaxies have linewidths of ~450-500 km/s, and thus we aim to detect the line signal in independent channels of 150 km/s each (bandwidth used for sensitivity). We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~7.8 MHz (16 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 16 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

We request unresolved (>1") observations of SPT0243-49. In this case, we aim to obtain a spatially integrated line measurement rather than resolving the source, given the relatively compact structure of the lens. In the case of SPT0346-52, the lens structure is sufficiently extended that the 1" resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2; see the technical justification for the science goals of SPT0346-52).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). Using these spectra as templates, we can scale the fluxes of observed galaxies in both redshift and 1.4-mm flux to derive the expected flux for our objects. This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in cycle-0 to a difference of < 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-redshift transitions are realistic. In SPT0243-49, only spatially unresolved measurements are feasible, so the requested sensitivity assumes no dilution of the source flux over multiple beams. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations. For SPT0243-49, we assume a linewidth of 500 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. At the requested rms level of 0.3 mJy, we expect to detect each of the targeted lines with a SNR > 3 in independent channels of 150 km/s. The line signal will be collapsed over the full linewidth to provide an integrated line measurement and increase the SN of the detections.

This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in cycle-0 to a difference of < 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-redshift transitions are realistic. In SPT0243-49, only spatially unresolved measurements are feasible, so the requested sensitivity assumes no dilution of the source flux over multiple beams. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations. For SPT0243-49, we assume a linewidth of 500 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. At the requested rms level of 0.2 mJy, we expect to detect each of the targeted lines with a SNR > 3 in independent channels of 150 km/s. The line signal will be collapsed over the full linewidth to provide an integrated line measurement and increase the SN of the detections.

The three requested tunings in band-4 are carefully chosen to maximize the coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.
While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000 km/s (>2 FWHM) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high-velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize the coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500 km/s blueward of their CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our band-3 tunings. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises.
Finally, we note that the galaxies have linewidths of ~450-500 km/s, and thus we aim to detect the line signal in independent channels of 150 km/s each (bandwidth used for sensitivity). We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~7.8 MHz (16 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 16 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

For SPT0346-52, we request a resolution of ~1". This resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based lens modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013; Spilker et al. 2015).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). Using these spectra as templates, we can scale the fluxes of observed galaxies in both redshift and 1.4-mm flux to derive the expected flux for our objects. This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in cycle-0 to a difference of < 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-redshift transitions are realistic. Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
For SPT0346-52, we assume a linewidth of 450 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. At the requested rms level of 0.3 mJy, we expect to detect each of the targeted lines with a SNR > 3 in independent channels of 150 km/s. The line signal will be collapsed over the full linewidth to provide an integrated line measurement and increase the SN of the detections.

The three requested tunings in band-4 are carefully chosen to maximize the coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.

While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises.
Finally, we note that the galaxies have linewidths of ~450-500 km/s, and thus we aim to detect the line signal in independent channels of 150 km/s each (bandwidth used for sensitivity). We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~7.8 MHz (16 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 16 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

For SPT0346-52, we request a resolution of ~1". This resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based lens modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013; Spilker et al. 2015).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.

Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.
While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000 km/s (>2 FWHM) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high-velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize the coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500 km/s blueward of their CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our band-3 tunings. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises.
Finally, we note that the galaxies have linewidths of ~450-500 km/s, and thus we aim to detect the line signal in independent channels of 150 km/s each (bandwidth used for sensitivity). We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~3.9 MHz (12 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 12 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

For SPT0346-52, we request a resolution of ~1". This resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based lens modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013; Spilker et al. 2015).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). Using these spectra as templates, we can scale the fluxes of observed galaxies in both redshift and 1.4-mm flux to derive the expected flux for our objects. This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in cycle-0 to a difference of < 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-redshift transitions are realistic. Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
For SPT0346-52, we assume a linewidth of 450 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. At the requested rms level of 0.23 mJy, we expect to detect each of the targeted lines with a SNR > 3 in independent channels of 150 km/s. The line signal will be collapsed over the full linewidth to provide an integrated line measurement and increase the SN of the detections.

The three requested tunings in band-4 are carefully chosen to maximize the coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.
While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000 km/s (>2 FWHM) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high-velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize the coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500 km/s blueward of their CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our band-3 tunings. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises.
Finally, we note that the galaxies have linewidths of ~450-500 km/s, and thus we aim to detect the line signal in independent channels of 150 km/s each (bandwidth used for sensitivity). We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~3.9 MHz (12 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 12 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

For SPT0346-52, we request a resolution of ~1". This resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based lens modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013; Spilker et al. 2015).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). Using these spectra as templates, we can scale the fluxes of observed galaxies in both redshift and 1.4-mm flux to derive the expected flux for our objects. This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in cycle-0 to a difference of < 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-redshift transitions are realistic. Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
For SPT0346-52, we assume a linewidth of 450 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. At the requested rms level of 0.23 mJy, we expect to detect each of the targeted lines with a SNR > 3 in independent channels of 150 km/s. The line signal will be collapsed over the full linewidth to provide an integrated line measurement and increase the SN of the detections.

The three requested tunings in band-4 are carefully chosen to maximize the coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The linewidths of these two sources are quite broad, ~450-500 km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines.
While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000 km/s (>2 FWHM) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high-velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize the coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500 km/s blueward of their CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our band-3 tunings. We have chosen to set the correlator in FDM mode with a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz per SPW, and a channel width of ~3.9 MHz (12 km/s) after spectral averaging to minimize data rate. These 12 km/s channels will then be averaged to 150 km/s (or coarser) for detection.

For SPT0346-52, we request a resolution of ~1". This resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lens images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based lens modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013; Spilker et al. 2015).

Our sensitivity requirements in band-4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, e.g., Arp220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC1068, a Seyfert-2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of the line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that the integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
For SPT0346-52, we assume a linewidth of 450 km/s. The bandwidth of 150 km/s used for our calculation was chosen to resolve the line over 3 independent channels. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a full molecular line inventory in Bands 3 and 4 of the two highest known redshift dusty starburst galaxies accessible by ALMA, at z=5.7, close to the end of cosmic reionization. A carefully-constructed tuning setup targets more than 40 lines of 13 molecular species expected to be detectable in these objects, tracing the full range of excitation conditions, heating mechanisms, outflow and dynamical signatures, and chemical enrichment pathways. At these rest frequencies, our observations will match and even exceed the sensitivity of local starbursts observed by Herschel/SPIRE. By exploiting high-resolution ALMA 870um continuum observations, low- and mid-J CO observations with ATCA and ALMA, [CII] emission from APEX, and full optical-to-radio SED coverage, these observations will stand as the definitive view of the ISM conditions in these objects, serving as an effective comparative study to local starbursts (e.g. Arp220) and intermediate-redshift analog systems (e.g. the Eyelash). In one target, we aim to spatially resolve the molecular line emission, allowing a 1 kpc-scale study of the near-Eddington-limited star formation underway in this object.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of cycle-2 program 2013.1.00722.S (PI: M. Aravena).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
